awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Mechanisms of nuclear rupture and repair in C. elegans
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal studies the mechanism of cell nucleus rupture and repair in vivo. Animal cells contain specialized structures, called organelles, which are bounded by a membrane and perform specific functions critical for cell survival. The most prominent organelle in animal cells is the nucleus that houses the cell's genetic material and protects it from damage. Exciting observations in the past few years of metastatic cancer cells and immune cells migrating in vitro have shown that cell nuclei can rupture and be damaged severely, however surprisingly cells can repair the nucleus and the cell can continue to live.  With this award, the PI will study inside how, a living organism, the nucleus performs its protective function. This research focuses on how nuclei stay intact when forces within cells and tissues are imposed on them. This work will reveal the basic principles of how the nucleus encases and protects the cell's genetic material, which is essential to cell and organismal survival. During the project period, an interactive hands-on workshop that is part of the Yale Pathways to Science Program will provide local high school students an authentic research experience enabling them to see the purpose of using model organisms in science discovery and solving societal problems. The goal of the workshop is to provide URM and female students that have traditionally had their thoughts underrepresented in the sciences a lens into the daily life and excitement of a scientist and, ultimately, help them gain confidence and motivation to persist in the sciences. The workshop curriculum will be refined and made available online in a web-based format to be used as a resource by other universities.

The nuclear envelope forms a physical barrier that serves to regulate and protect the genome. In contrast to the textbook description of the nuclear envelope as a static barrier between the nucleoplasm and cytoplasm, the nuclear envelope is highly dynamic and undergoes local membrane remodeling such as membrane budding, fusion, rupture and repair, as well as global membrane remodeling in open mitosis. Transient nuclear ruptures are a type of local remodeling in which a region of the nuclear envelope ruptures and is subsequently resealed to restore genome compartmentalization. Little is known about how the nuclear envelope prevents ruptures, and promotes repair of ruptures to ensure genome protection, especially in vivo. The objective of this research project is to define the underlying principles of nuclear rupture and repair in a living, intact organism. The research will use the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans, a simple, transparent nematode that undergoes invariant development allowing for quantitative analysis of nuclear envelope dynamics during cellular and tissue morphogenesis. The research project will also employ a combination of innovative laser cutting tools, mathematical predictions, and RNAi-mediated perturbations. The findings are likely to be of broad importance to understanding nuclear envelope dynamics and genome protection in diverse cellular processes and behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the funding period, our team of graduate students and postdocs investigated how the membrane that separates the genome from the cytoplasm—the nuclear envelope—maintains its integrity. The nuclear envelope contains specialized gateways that regulate communication between the nucleus and the rest of the cell. However, mechanical forces exerted on nuclei during dynamic cellular processes can cause ruptures in this membrane, leading to uncontrolled mixing of nuclear and cytoplasmic contents, which can expose the genome to damage. Fortunately, specialized repair machinery exists to restore nuclear envelope integrity, functioning similarly to a multi-layered security system.

Before this project, most studies on nuclear envelope repair were conducted in tissue culture cells, where the forces acting on nuclei differ from those in unconfined cells and tissues within an intact organism. Additionally, studying repair processes was challenging due to their rare occurrence and rapid resolution. To overcome these limitations, we established C. elegans, a simple roundworm, as a model organism for investigating nuclear envelope repair. This system allowed us to combine time-lapse imaging with genomic engineering tools to analyze the repair process in a living organism.

Our research revealed that nuclear envelope repair is a natural part of early developmental processes, particularly during the initial formation of the nucleus after fertilization. We discovered that even large holes—on the micron scale—can be sealed by repair machinery, challenging the previous belief that this system was only effective for small perforations. Our findings also demonstrated that the production of lipids, the essential building blocks of membranes, is regulated during repair. Interestingly, an excess of membranes near the damage site can hinder proper sealing. We also analyzed how that the addition of membranes to increase the surface area of the nuclear membrane is related to the transport of factors inside the nucleus to regulate nuclear growth following the nuclear formation. We went on to biochemically define the proteins that are involved in lipid synthesis to reveal how they conduct these functions for nuclear envelope repair. 

Furthermore, we found that repair machinery can navigate around obstacles such as the mitotic spindle to ensure successful closure of large nuclear envelope breaches. A major breakthrough was uncovering the redundancy within the repair system—multiple layers of molecular safeguards work together to ensure the nucleus is properly sealed and formed. By dissecting these layers, we gained crucial insights into how cells protect the integrity of the genome during the earliest stages of development.

As we pursue discovery-based research, we place a strong emphasis on disseminating scientific knowledge and training the next generation of scientists and informed citizens in our community. In collaboration with the Yale-sponsored Pathways to Science program, we lead a summer workshop titled "Model Organisms in Biology: The Mighty Worm," which introduces New Haven high school students to biological research and the critical role of model organisms in scientific discovery.

We continuously develop and refine our curriculum, which has consistently received high ratings from participating students. The workshop is run entirely by trainees in our laboratory, who also manage logistics, ensuring the sustainability of our outreach efforts year after year.

In sum, our scientific research, training, and outreach have resulted in multiple published discoveries while sustaining long-term outreach efforts and equipping scientists with the skills to pursue diverse career paths.
